results.title: The Union man
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, International Television Federation, Ivan Chapman and John Gray
results.brief_description: An examination of trade unionism in Australia, the United States and Britain. Includes a visit to the English village of Tolpuddle, the cradle of unionism. Sixty per cent of Australian wage earners are union members, including stock riders and shearers in the outback as well as the two million city unionists. Prominence is given to the notorious waterside workers - a report on working conditions won by them over the years; a typical stop-work meeting; a lecture by a union official.

results.title: The Unification of Italy
results.brief_description: The long struggle to create a unified Italy from the invasion by Napoleon in 1805 to the plebiscite of Rome in 1870. The important events are re-enacted against historic locales in Italy, showing the roles played by Mazzini, King Victor Emmanuel, Count Cavour and Garibaldi.

results.title: The Unicorn in the garden
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, United Productions of America, Stephen Bosustow and William T. Hurtz
results.brief_description:
Based on a short story by James Thurber, this is a gentle reminder that people do not always see things as we do. A poor henpecked husband sees a unicorn in his garden and excitedly tells his wife. She calls the police and a psychiatrist, wanting him to be committed, but in the end it is she who is taken away.
Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Ungrateful land: Roch Carrier remembers Ste-Justine
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Ian McLaren and Cynthia Scott
results.brief_description: Here is the village of St. Justine as one gifted man, novelist and playwright Roch carrier, remembers, it. In this small corner of Quebec there is space in the landscape and in the vast spread of forest, but the fringe of rocks around every field speaks of the back-breaking hardship that was the lot Carrier’s father and his grandfather before him. This is a nostalgic view of rural Quebec and its people, from a man who feels and cares. Narrated by Roch Carrier.

results.title: The Unfaithful wife = La Femme infidele [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Les Films La Boetie, Cinegai, Andre Genoves and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description: This darkly amusing and accurately observed off-beat thriller established Chabrol as a master of the genre. An apparently happily married man has his bourgeois complacency shattered by the discovery of his wife’s infidelity. Murder is a sudden eruption that only momentarily shatters the niceties of middle class life. Chabrol is neither entirely cynical nor wholly compassionate in his cool dissection of a bourgeois marriage. This film is the first of a trilogy on adultery known as the ‘Helene’ series (all starring Chabrol’s then wife, Stephane Audran) including ‘La Rupture/The Breakup’. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Stephane Audran, Michel Bouquet, Michel Duchaussoy and Maurice Ronet. The film was remade in 2002 as ‘Unfaithful’ (directed by Adrian Lyne) also scripted by Chabrol.

results.title: The Unfair go
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Con Anemogiannis and Ian Munro
results.brief_description: A 6 part program which uses comments from academics, social workers and politicians to discuss the welfare system in Australia. Explores the plight and welfare of Australians and analyses the state of our welfare system in relation to Great Britain, United States, Sweden, Soviet Union, Uruguay and Peru. Contents: The growing divide (29 min.), A net full of holes (28 min.), The sorry state (29 min.), The kindness of strangers (29 min.), Battlers or bludgers (29 min.), Who gives a buck (28 min.). Narrated by Jim Downes.

results.title: The Unexplained cannibals
results.brief_description: Is cannibalism part of human nature? That is the question posed to us in this documentary that looks at cannibalism from ancient human history to modern day incidents. Society’s dual fascination and revulsion of the subject has made cannibalism a continual taboo. Psychiatrists believe it is human nature and when the mind adapts and survival depends on it - we accept it. The practise of cannibalism is one of survival, tribal ritual and madness. We look at the factors affecting the Donner party in 1846, a group of pioneers heading to California who became stranded in a snow storm and had to partake in cannibalism for their survival. We are introduced to Ed Gein, one of America’s most notorious serial killers who used to boil up parts of his victim’s bodies to eat, and learn about the religious rituals practised by tribes of New Guinea, as related by anthropologist Fitz John Poole PD who lived with the tribes for three years. The documentary looks at the various reasons behind why people become cannibals and poses the question, “why is it such a psychological taboo?”.
